org.gearvrf

Class GVRPicker

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.gearvrf.GVRHybridObject
      • org.gearvrf.GVRComponent
        • org.gearvrf.GVRBehavior
          • org.gearvrf.GVRPicker
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    GVRDrawFrameListener
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    GVRFrustumPicker, GVRObjectPicker

    public class GVRPicker
extends GVRBehavior
    Finds the scene objects that are hit by a ray. The picker can function in two modes. One way is to simply call its static functions to make a single scan through the scene to determine what is hit by the picking ray. The other way is to add the picker as a component to a scene object. The picking ray is generated from the camera viewpoint each frame. It's origin is the camera position and it's direction is the camera forward look vector (what the user is looking at). For a scene object to be pickable, it must have a GVRCollider component attached to it that is enabled. The picker "casts" a ray into the screen graph, and returns an array containing all the collisions as instances of GVRPickedObject. The picked object contains the collider instance hit, the distance from the camera and the hit position. The picker maintains the list of currently picked objects (which can be obtained with getPicked()) and continually updates it each frame. In this mode, when the ray from the scene object hits a pickable object, the picker generates one or more pick events (IPickEvents interface) which are sent the event receiver of the scene. These events can be observed by listeners. - onEnter(GVRSceneObject) called when the pick ray enters a scene object. - onExit(GVRSceneObject) called when the pick ray exits a scene object. - onInside(GVRSceneObject) called while the pick ray penetrates a scene object. - onPick(GVRPicker) called when the set of picked objects changes. - onNoPick(GVRPicker) called once when nothing is picked.
    See Also:
    IPickEvents, GVRSceneObject.attachCollider(GVRCollider), GVRCollider, GVRComponent.setEnable(boolean), GVRPicker.GVRPickedObject

    • Constructor Detail

      • GVRPicker

        public GVRPicker(GVRContext context,
                 GVRScene scene)
        Construct a picker which picks from a given scene. Instantiating the picker will cause it to scan the scene every frame and generate pick events based on the result.
        Parameters:
        context - context that owns the scene
        scene - scene containing the scene objects to pick from

    • Method Detail

      • getComponentType

        public static long getComponentType()

      • getPickRay

        public float[] getPickRay()
        Get the current ray to use for picking. If the picker is attached to a scene object, this ray is derived from the scene object's transform. The origin of the ray is the translation component of the total model matrix and the ray direction is the forward look vector. If not attached to a scene object, the origin of the ray is the position of the viewer and its direction is where the viewer is looking.
        Returns:
        pick ray

      • getPicked

        public final GVRPicker.GVRPickedObject[] getPicked()
        Gets the current pick list. Each collision with an object is described as a GVRPickedObject which contains the scene object and collider hit, the distance from the camera and the hit position in the coordinate system of the collision geometry. The objects in the pick list are sorted based on increasing distance from the origin of the pick ray.
        Returns:
        GVRPickedObject array with objects picked or null if nothing picked.
        See Also:
        doPick(), IPickEvents, setPickRay(float, float, float, float, float, float)

      • setPickRay

        public void setPickRay(float ox,
                       float oy,
                       float oz,
                       float dx,
                       float dy,
                       float dz)
        Sets the origin and direction of the pick ray.
        Parameters:
        ox - X coordinate of origin.
        oy - Y coordinate of origin.
        oz - Z coordinate of origin.
        dx - X coordinate of ray direction.
        dy - Y coordinate of ray direction.
        dz - Z coordinate of ray direction. The coordinate system of the ray depends on the whether the picker is attached to a scene object or not. When attached to a scene object, the ray is in the coordinate system of that object where (0, 0, 0) is the center of the scene object and (0, 0, 1) is it's positive Z axis. If not attached to an object, the ray is in the coordinate system of the scene's main camera with (0, 0, 0) at the viewer and (0, 0, -1) where the viewer is looking.
        See Also:
        doPick()

      • onDrawFrame

        public void onDrawFrame(float frameTime)
        Description copied from class: GVRBehavior
        Called each frame before rendering the scene. It is not called if this behavior is not attached to a GVRSceneObject.
        Specified by:

        Overrides:

        Parameters:
        frameTime - Seconds since the previous frame - see GVRContext.getFrameTime()

      • doPick

        protected void doPick()
        Scans the scene graph to collect picked items and generates appropriate pick events. This function is called automatically by the picker every frame.
        See Also:
        IPickEvents, pickObjects(GVRScene, float, float, float, float, float, float)

      • generatePickEvents

        protected void generatePickEvents(GVRPicker.GVRPickedObject[] picked)

      • pickScene

        public static final GVREyePointeeHolder[] pickScene(GVRScene scene,
                                                    float ox,
                                                    float oy,
                                                    float oz,
                                                    float dx,
                                                    float dy,
                                                    float dz)
        Deprecated. use pickObjects instead
        Casts a ray into the scene graph, and returns the GVREyePointeeHolders it intersects. The ray is defined by its origin [ox, oy, oz] and its direction [dx, dy, dz].

        The ray origin may be [0, 0, 0] and the direction components should be normalized from -1 to 1: Note that the y direction runs from -1 at the bottom to 1 at the top. To construct a picking ray originating at the user's head and pointing into the scene along the camera lookat vector, pass in 0, 0, 0 for the origin and 0, 0, -1 for the direction.

        Note: this function only returns GVREyePointeeHolder colliders and is deprecated in favor of pickObject which returns all colliders.

        Parameters:
        scene - The GVRScene with all the objects to be tested.
        ox - The x coordinate of the ray origin.
        oy - The y coordinate of the ray origin.
        oz - The z coordinate of the ray origin.
        dx - The x vector of the ray direction.
        dy - The y vector of the ray direction.
        dz - The z vector of the ray direction.
        Returns:
        The colliders penetrated by the ray, sorted by distance from the camera rig. Use GVRComponent.getOwnerObject() to get the corresponding scene objects.

      • pickScene

        public static final GVREyePointeeHolder[] pickScene(GVRScene scene)
        Deprecated. use pickObjects instead
        Tests the GVRSceneObjects contained within scene against the camera rig's lookat vector. Note: this function only returns GVREyePointeeHolder colliders and is deprecated in favor of pickObject which returns all colliders.
        Parameters:
        scene - The GVRScene with all the objects to be tested.
        Returns:
        the array of GVREyePointeeHolder objects which are penetrated by the picking ray. They are sorted by distance from the camera.

      • pickSceneObject

        public static final float pickSceneObject(GVRSceneObject sceneObject,
                                          GVRCameraRig cameraRig)
        Tests the GVRSceneObject against the camera rig's lookat vector.
        Parameters:
        sceneObject - The GVRSceneObject to be tested.
        cameraRig - The GVRCameraRig to use for ray testing.
        Returns:
        the distance from the camera rig. It returns positive infinity if the cameraRig is not pointing to the sceneObject.

      • pickObjects

        public static final GVRPicker.GVRPickedObject[] pickObjects(GVRScene scene,
                                                            float ox,
                                                            float oy,
                                                            float oz,
                                                            float dx,
                                                            float dy,
                                                            float dz)
        Casts a ray into the scene graph, and returns the objects it intersects. The ray is defined by its origin [ox, oy, oz] and its direction [dx, dy, dz].

        The ray origin may be [0, 0, 0] and the direction components should be normalized from -1 to 1: Note that the y direction runs from -1 at the bottom to 1 at the top. To construct a picking ray originating at the user's head and pointing into the scene along the camera lookat vector, pass in 0, 0, 0 for the origin and 0, 0, -1 for the direction.

        This method is thread safe because it guarantees that only one thread at a time is doing a ray cast into a particular scene graph, and it extracts the hit data during within its synchronized block. You can then examine the return list without worrying about another thread corrupting your hit data. Depending on the type of collider, that the hit location may not be exactly where the ray would intersect the scene object itself. Rather, it is where the ray intersects the collision geometry associated with the collider.

        Parameters:
        scene - The GVRScene with all the objects to be tested.
        ox - The x coordinate of the ray origin.
        oy - The y coordinate of the ray origin.
        oz - The z coordinate of the ray origin.
        dx - The x vector of the ray direction.
        dy - The y vector of the ray direction.
        dz - The z vector of the ray direction.
        Returns:
        A list of GVRPicker.GVRPickedObject, sorted by distance from the camera rig. Each GVRPicker.GVRPickedObject contains the scene object which owns the GVRCollider along with the hit location and distance from the camera.
        Since:
        1.6.6

      • pickObjects

        public static final GVRPicker.GVRPickedObject[] pickObjects(GVRScene scene,
                                                            GVRTransform trans,
                                                            float ox,
                                                            float oy,
                                                            float oz,
                                                            float dx,
                                                            float dy,
                                                            float dz)
        Casts a ray into the scene graph, and returns the objects it intersects. The ray is defined by its origin [ox, oy, oz] and its direction [dx, dy, dz]. The ray is in the coordinate system of the input transform, allowing it to be with respect to a scene object.

        The ray origin may be [0, 0, 0] and the direction components should be normalized from -1 to 1: Note that the y direction runs from -1 at the bottom to 1 at the top. To construct a picking ray originating at the center of a scene object and pointing where that scene object looks, attach the GVRPicker to the scene object and pass (0, 0, 0) as the ray origin and (0, 0, -1) for the direction.

        This method is thread safe because it guarantees that only one thread at a time is doing a ray cast into a particular scene graph, and it extracts the hit data during within its synchronized block. You can then examine the return list without worrying about another thread corrupting your hit data. Depending on the type of collider, that the hit location may not be exactly where the ray would intersect the scene object itself. Rather, it is where the ray intersects the collision geometry associated with the collider.

        Parameters:
        scene - The GVRScene with all the objects to be tested.
        trans - The GVRTransform establishing the coordinate system of the ray.
        ox - The x coordinate of the ray origin.
        oy - The y coordinate of the ray origin.
        oz - The z coordinate of the ray origin.
        dx - The x vector of the ray direction.
        dy - The y vector of the ray direction.
        dz - The z vector of the ray direction.
        Returns:
        A list of GVRPicker.GVRPickedObject, sorted by distance from the camera rig. Each GVRPicker.GVRPickedObject contains the scene object which owns the GVRCollider along with the hit location and distance from the camera.
        Since:
        1.6.6

      • findObjects

        public static final java.util.List<GVRPicker.GVRPickedObject> findObjects(GVRScene scene,
                                                                          float ox,

        Casts a ray into the scene graph, and returns the objects it intersects.

      • findObjects

        public static final java.util.List<GVRPicker.GVRPickedObject> findObjects(GVRScene scene)
        Tests the GVRSceneObjects contained within scene against the camera rig's lookat vector.

        This method uses higher-level function findObjects() internally.

        Parameters:
        scene - The GVRScene with all the objects to be tested.
        Returns:
        A list of GVRPicker.GVRPickedObject, sorted by distance from the camera rig. Each GVRPicker.GVRPickedObject contains the object within the GVREyePointeeHolder along with the hit location.
